metadata.Description: Well organized and easy to understand Web building tutorials with lots of examples of how to use HTML, CSS, JavaScript, SQL, Python, PHP, Bootstrap, Java, XML and more.
metadata.og:description: W3Schools offers free online tutorials, references and exercises in all the major languages of the web. Covering popular subjects like HTML, CSS, JavaScript, Python, SQL, Java, and many, many more.

content.text: Arithmetic operators perform arithmetic on numbers (literals or variables).
content.html: Arithmetic operators perform arithmetic on numbers (literals or variables).

content.text: A typical arithmetic operation operates on two numbers.
content.html: A typical arithmetic operation operates on two numbers.

content.text: The two numbers can be literals:
content.html: The two numbers can be literals:

content.code_html: let x = 100 + 50;

content.html: or variables:

content.code_html: let x = a + b;

content.html: or expressions:

content.code_html: let x = (100 + 50) * a;

content.text: The numbers (in an arithmetic operation) are called operands .
content.html: The numbers (in an arithmetic operation) are called operands.

content.text: The operation (to be performed between the two operands) is defined by an operator .
content.html: The operation (to be performed between the two operands) is defined by an operator.
The addition operator (+) adds numbers:

content.code_html:
let x = 5;
let y = 2;
let z = x + y;

content.html: The subtraction operator (-) subtracts numbers.

content.code_html:
let x = 5;
let y = 2;
let z = x - y;

content.html: The multiplication operator (*) multiplies numbers.

content.code_html:
let x = 5;
let y = 2;
let z = x * y;

content.html: The division operator (/) divides numbers.

content.code_html:
let x = 5;
let y = 2;
let z = x / y;

content.text: The modulus operator ( % ) returns the division remainder.
content.html: The modulus operator (%) returns the division remainder.

content.code_html:
let x = 5;
let y = 2;
let z = x % y;

content.text: In arithmetic, the division of two integers produces a quotient and a remainder .
content.html: In arithmetic, the division of two integers produces a quotient and a remainder.

content.text: In mathematics, the result of a modulo operation is the remainder of an arithmetic division.
content.html: In mathematics, the result of a modulo operation is the remainder of an arithmetic division.
The increment operator (++) increments numbers.

content.code_html:
let x = 5;
x++;
let z = x;

content.html: The decrement operator (--) decrements numbers.

content.code_html:
let x = 5;
x--;
let z = x;

content.text: The exponentiation operator ( ** ) raises the first operand to the power of the second operand.
content.html: The exponentiation operator (**) raises the first operand to the power of the second operand.

content.code_html:
let x = 5;
let z = x ** 2;

content.text: x ** y produces the same result as Math.pow(x,y) :
content.html: x ** y produces the same result as Math.pow(x,y):

content.code_html:
let x = 5;
let z = Math.pow(x,2);

content.text: Operator precedence describes the order in which operations are performed in an arithmetic expression.
content.html: Operator precedence describes the order in which operations are performed in an arithmetic expression.

content.code_html: let x = 100 + 50 * 3;

content.text: Is the result of example above the same as 150 * 3, or is it the same as 100 + 150?
content.html: Is the result of example above the same as 150 * 3, or is it the same as 100 + 150?

content.text: Is the addition or the multiplication done first?
content.html: Is the addition or the multiplication done first?

content.text: As in traditional school mathematics, the multiplication is done first.
content.html: As in traditional school mathematics, the multiplication is done first.

content.text: Multiplication ( * ) and division ( / ) have higher precedence than addition ( + ) and subtraction ( - ).
content.html: Multiplication (*) and division (/) have higher precedence than addition (+) and subtraction (-).

content.text: And (as in school mathematics) the precedence can be changed by using parentheses.
content.html: And (as in school mathematics) the precedence can be changed by using parentheses.

content.text: When using parentheses, the operations inside the parentheses are computed first:
content.html: When using parentheses, the operations inside the parentheses are computed first:

content.code_html: let x = (100 + 50) * 3;

content.text: When many operations have the same precedence (like addition and subtraction or multiplication and division), they are computed from left to right:
content.html: When many operations have the same precedence (like addition and subtraction or multiplication and division), they are computed from left to right:

content.code_html: let x = 100 + 50 - 3;

content.text: For a full list of operator precedence values go to:
content.html: For a full list of operator precedence values go to:
JavaScript Operator Precedence Values.

content.text: Exercise ? What is this? Test your skills by answering a few questions about the topics of this page
Consider the following code: let x = 5; x++; What will be the result of x ?
content.html:
Consider the following code:
let x = 5;
x++;
What will be the result of x?

metadata.question: Consider the following code:let x = 5;x++;What will be the result of x?

content.question: Consider the following code:let x = 5;x++;What will be the result of x?
